head.title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2001 Mercedes-Benz SLK320; Show-Stopping Top Gets Engine to Match

hedline.hl1: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2001 Mercedes-Benz SLK320; Show-Stopping Top Gets Engine to Match

abstract.p: Behind the Wheel article appraises 2001 Mercedes-Benz SLK320, which starts at $44,545, with options that can add $10,000 more; photo (M)

block.p: THE last time I drove a Mercedes-Benz SLK, I couldn't lower the retractable hardtop. Not because it didn't work; it was buried under a half-foot pile of snow.

That was during a dreary Michigan winter. This time, with temperatures temporarily near 90 under a broiling sun, the roof came down once and stayed there. The car was sunnier, too: It was a new-for-2001 model, the SLK320, with a 215-horsepower V-6 stuffed in the engine compartment.
THE last time I drove a Mercedes-Benz SLK, I couldn't lower the retractable hardtop. Not because it didn't work; it was buried under a half-foot pile of snow.

That was during a dreary Michigan winter. This time, with temperatures temporarily near 90 under a broiling sun, the roof came down once and stayed there. The car was sunnier, too: It was a new-for-2001 model, the SLK320, with a 215-horsepower V-6 stuffed in the engine compartment.

The original version, the SLK230 Kompressor that arrived in January 1997, was a sales success. Mercedes had to double production to meet American demand. That car, like the new 320, had a sexy wedge shape and the retractable roof, a marvel of engineering capable of stopping traffic when it went up or down, the various panels whirring open as the roof lifted, folded and dropped out of sight -- all at the touch of one button in about half a minute.

But the SLK230 had one nagging inadequacy: It didn't feel very sporty. Even with its supercharger, the four-cylinder engine was barely adequate for such a solid, heavy car. Sports car purists also lamented the lack of a manual transmission.

The four-cylinder SLK230 is still around -- its horsepower rating inched up 5 for 2001, to 190 -- but most American drivers will find the new 320 more to their liking. This car has a version of the 3.2-liter V-6 engine used in several Mercedes products. The V-6 has peak torque of 229 foot-pounds, compared with 200 for the old car.

The performance difference is impressive. While the larger engine supposedly shaves only half a second from the SLK's 0-to-60 acceleration time, to about 6.6 seconds, stoplight getaways feel far more exhilarating. And the SLK320 makes a throaty growl as the engine revs.

Both SLK models are now available with a six-speed manual transmission, although a five-speed automatic continues to be offered. The six-speed is a big improvement over the notchy five-speed manual that was added to the 230 Kompressor last year, but its shift action is more mushy than crisp, and it sometimes balked at sliding smoothly into gear.

While the V-6 and six-speed transform the SLK into a sporty package that can be driven hard, the car still rides more comfortably than most imported roadsters. (A sport package with a tighter suspension is optional.) With the top down, the solid Mercedes structure virtually eliminates body shake, and with it up, the car feels as well-braced and weatherproof as a coupe. This is one convertible that truly can be used year-round in the North.
My only other complaint with the SLK320 was with its steering, which required extra effort to keep the car headed straight under hard acceleration.

The body shape is the same, reminiscent of Mercedes roadsters of the 50's, but the front and rear have been updated subtly. Taillamps have clear covers; turn indicators are incorporated into the side mirrors.

Inside, the SLK still has retro gauges (attractive, but not always perfectly legible), but the fake carbon-fiber trim of the original car is gone. The V-6 car has wood inserts; the four-cylinder version uses brushed aluminum. Both models have Tele Aid, an emergency communications system like General Motors' OnStar, and antiskid controls.

To make room for the new car, Mercedes lowered the price of the SLK230 Kompressor by about $2,000, to $39,545 including shipping charges. The SLK320 starts at $44,545, but options can quickly add $10,000 or more.

I was always a fan of the SLK, which has sold especially well among women. Its classy style cost half as much as Mercedes's top-of-the-line SL-Series roadsters. It rode more comfortably than the Porsche Boxster or BMW Z3, and its solid top made it usable year-round. The zippy new powertrain makes it sporty as well as stylish.
INSIDE TRACK: SLK is short for ''slick.''
